A 48-year-old man presented with complaints of aforeign body sensation in nose and frequent spitting of blood-tinged saliva for 6 months duration. On examination, a reddish pedunculated mass studded with whitish spots was seen hanging in nasal cavity. On nasal endoscopy, mass was seen attached along the under surface of left inferior turbinate, which bled on contact. The patient also gave history of taking frequent baths in local ponds. After a clinical diagnosis of rhinosporidisis, he underwent complete excision of the mass after ipolar cauterisation of the base under local anaesthesis.Postoperative histopathology revealed multiple sporangia in various stages of maturation with dense inflammation.Choose the most appropriate diagnosis
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Key Diagnostic Clues in the Case:
  • • Presentation: Nasal mass with recurrent epistaxis and foreign body sensation
  • • Exposure: History of bathing in stagnant pond water (a known source of infection)
  • • Appearance: Reddish, vascular pedunculated mass with white spots (mature sporangia)
  • • Bleeds on touch: Common in rhinosporidial lesions
  • • Histology: Large thick-walled sporangia containing numerous endospores in various stages of development
  • • Management: Complete surgical excision with cauterization of base to prevent recurrence
  • • Incorrect Options:
  • • Incorrect Options:
  • • Option A: Rhinoscleroma Caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis
  • • Chronic, slowly progressive infection of nose and upper airway
  • • Histology shows Mikulicz cells (foamy macrophages), not sporangia
  • • Not associated with white dots or pond exposure
  • • Option C: Angiofibroma Seen in adolescent males
  • • Highly vascular tumor presenting with profuse epistaxis
  • • Usually arises from sphenopalatine foramen, not inferior turbinate
  • • No sporangia seen on histology
  • • Option D: Nasal Polyp Soft, painless, edematous mucosal outgrowth
  • • Associated with allergies, asthma
  • • Does not bleed easily on touch
  • • No white spots or sporangia
